title: Can a student start writing newspaper articles? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why not? Your very question shows that you have sn urge for writing. That's enough for a start. You can start writing straight away. This urge is the backbone of the attempt. Don't expect any spectacular admiration from the public at once. On other hand, if you get it, you are very lucky. Writing, in most cases, tends to be an uphill task! You must be able to sustain your interest. Endless reading is the key to good and successful writing . You must be thinking about it day in and day out. It must be a job of love. Success will breed success. Talk to people who are knowledgeable. Get their ideas. There will be an interaction in your mind between their and your ideas. That's the pleasure to be devoutly wished for. If you have other means of sustenance, you can pursue this with will and vigour. The first praise Will take care of the rest! All the best to you!

Yes. Age is no barrier. Yet a beginner is best off starting with their church or school newspaper. Saleable articles pretty much require that you earn your chops. Your writing has to achieve polish and all the important stuff like vocabulary, grammar, and a general life sense. This where ‘non-pro’ situations come in. Small audiences let you begin to understand what readers like and don’t. You have various ‘editors’ to please even on these occasions. They DO have organizations, at least informally. It serves as a training ground. It doesn’t end with just one article. A following needs building, always! Quora is good. Upvotes are the way to track your personal progress. People come to know you as a solid source of info and interest with others. Your audience in other words. Getting asked back is the best compliment. You never know who is reading you.

You bet. School papers are a good starting point. If you live in a small town, you might approach your local newspaper. I have students in California, one in high school and another in eighth grade, who have published articles in their local papers. When I was in high school, I offered to write for my hometown newspaper for “bed, board, and bylines.” My offer was not accepted then. but after college, that publication gave me my first job in journalism. If you are in college, consider interning at a professional newspaper. Both paid and unpaid internships are available. They are a wonderful training ground. It sounds like you may soon be entering the most exciting profession on earth. Hang on tight — it’ll be quite a ride.

Can a student start writing newspaper articles? There have been student columnists in my local newspaper. Let me clarify that out of the hundreds of thousands of students in this university town, no more than two or three students at a time held that position. In other words, being a student does not disqualify you from writing for a newspaper, but not every student who likes to write will be accepted by the newspaper. Contact the paper to find out the possibilities. Perhaps if you have experience on the school paper, it could help, or courses in journalism, or prizes for your academic writing.

Sure. You can write for your school paper or start pitching various newspaper editors. For example, if you like sports, talk to the editor of the local weekly paper in your town and offer to go to area high school games and write about them for $25 per story. These should be 500–800 words and you may need to have access to a decent SLR camera, as well. You can talk to the team coach after the game to get quotes. At Campus News, we also take student -written stories. See: Campus News

Of course. If you don’t have a publisher, create a free blog at Quora or WordPress or Blogger and start reporting. Noting that you are a pre-med student, you could also apply for reporting internships with medical publishers. Prepare some reporting work to show your stuff, then don’t be shy.

response.answer_text: Hello!  If the student can convey his/her ideas clearly, convincingly and fluently, then yes, he/she can write newspaper articles. He/she would not be as experienced as journalists but with a lot of practice, notable reports can be produced. However, it is very probable that agencies will not agree to publish them at the beginning. They can still be posted online.
Of course. Getting them published is a different question, but there’s no reason not to start writing them. Practice is valuable, too.

Thank you for the A2A. I wrote my first published article when I was a third-grader (about the local school children getting the Salk polio vaccine on sugar cubes). Most newspapers are happy to have articles about things that happen in their primary market that would otherwise probably go uncovered, so just follow a couple of basic rules: Simple declarative sentences: “Jack ran down the hill.”Who, what, where, when, how and maybe why.Make sure you spell everyone’s name correctly.And if you can handle a camera, that’s a bonus.

Yep. Write for the school paper (or radio station, or TV station, or web site), if there is one. Is there a small local newspaper looking for copy? See if the editor is interested in giving you an assignment.
Thanks for the A2A. Sure. Some schools actually have a school newspaper, as well. If yours doesn’t, you might talk with whomever is in charge about starting one.
Anybody can. However the news must be current and relevant for any one to care about it.
